citation.article-title: Gordonia polyisoprenivorans sp. nov., a rubber-degrading actinomycete isolated from an automobile tyre

p.s: Description of Gordonia polyisoprenivorans sp. nov.
Gordonia polyisoprenivorans (poly.iso.preni'vor.ans. M .L. gen adj. polyisoprenivorans polyisoprene eating, referring to the ability to degrade polyisoprene)
Aerobic, Gram-positive, non-motile actinomycete which forms a rudimentary mycelium which fragments into rod/coccoid-like elements.
Colonies smooth, beige, pastel, orange when exposed to light.

Able to utilize acetamide, L-alanine, D-arabitol, L-aspartate, benzoate, 4-hydroxybenzoate, citrate, D-galactose, gluconate, D-glucosaminic acid, i-inositol, L-proline, quinate, putrescine, L-rhamnose, sucrose, D-turanose and L-valine.
No growth observed with 4-aminobenzoate, 3-hydroxybenzoate, caprate, D-glucarate, L-leucine, 2-oxoglutarate, pimelate, phenylacetate, D-ribose, L-serine, succinate and 2-hydroxyvalerate.
No hydrolysis of the chromogenic substrates, i.e. p-nitrophenyl-β-D-xyloside, p-nitrophenylphosphoryl choline and 2-desoxythymidine-5-p-nitrophenyplh osphate.
Whole-cell hydrolysates contain mesodiaminopimelic acid, arabinose and galactose (cell wall chemo type IV sensu Lechevalier & Lechevalier).
Sugars of the peptidoglycan are glycolated.
The polar lipids are composed of diphosphatidylglycerol, phosphatidylethanolamine, phosphatidylinositol and phosphatidylinositol mannosides.
The principal mycolic acids have chain lengths of 60 and 62 carbon atoms.
Able to solubilize and mineralize natural rubber substrates.
Isolated from fouling tyre water inside a deteriorated automobile tyre on a farmer's field in Munster, Germany.
Type strain: Gordonia polyisoprenivorans strain Kd2T (= DSM 44302T)
